creator: bradmongar@hotmail.com
text:
When writing Java applications using jsps I need to have all the files with 
the exact case for the file name.  This was not the case in the previous version 
of tomcat I was using.  
   I have confirmed that Apache does not force the case restriction, and my code 
that accesses files directly doesn't have the case restriction, so it is not and 
OS problem.
   Example if the filer were named http:\\localhost\Input.jsp then 
http:\\localhost\input.jsp would give a 404 error.

creator: Larry.Isaacs@sas.com
text:
The case sensitivity is by design, for security and protablility reasons.  A 
web application that depended on case insensitivity for correct operation 
wouldn't run on a case sensitive OS. Note that in some older Tomcats, such
as 3.1, you could get Tomcat to serve the JSP *source* by simply using
".jsP" as the extension instead of ".jsp".
